title: Zelda Kahan
text:
Zelda Kahan (1886 – 1969) was a British <a href="communist">communist</a>.
Born into a Jewish family in <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russia</a> in 1886, Kahan's family were forced to emigrate, and she moved to Britain at an early age. The Kahans lived at 6 <a href="Clapton%20Square">Clapton Square</a> in <a href="Hackney%20Central">Hackney</a>, London. She became an active socialist and joined the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Federation">Social Democratic Federation</a> (SDF). Within the SDF, she was a leading opponent of <a href="Ernest%20Belfort%20Bax">Ernest Belfort Bax</a>'s <a href="anti-feminism">anti-feminism</a>, and an ardent anti-militarist. After a resolution she proposed to the conference of the SDF's successor, the <a href="British%20Socialist%20Party">British Socialist Party</a>, was approved against the wishes of the party leadership, she was elected to its executive. She worked alongside <a href="Theodore%20Rothstein">Theodore Rothstein</a> in opposition to <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, and supported the foundation of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Great%20Britain">Communist Party of Great Britain</a> (CPGB).
Kahan married fellow communist <a href="William%20Peyton%20Coates">William Peyton Coates</a> (died 8 Aug 1963), and became known as Zelda Coates. Together, they set up the <a href="Anglo-Russian%20Parliamentary%20Committee">Anglo-Russian Parliamentary Committee</a>. 
The Coates lived at 37 Coolhurst Road, <a href="Hornsey">Hornsey</a>, London N8 in later days.
